newsitem.title: USA: Stocks hit new records; bonds, dollar rally on data.
newsitem.headline: Stocks hit new records; bonds, dollar rally on data.

text.p: Blue-chip stocks set another record Tuesday as long-term bond interest rates fell on economic news that eased inflation fears.
The dollar rose to the highest level against the German mark since July 1994 and rose to a 45-month peak vs. the Japanese yen.
The Dow Jones industrial average ended up 53.11 points at 6,762.29, its fourth straight record finish and sixth high of the year.
In the broader market, advancing issues led declines 1,800 to 802 on heavy volume of 531 million shares on the New York Stock Exchange.
The Nasdaq Composite, Standard & Poor's composite and the NYSE Composite indexes also set new highs.
Stocks got an early boost when key economic indicators for December confirmed inflation remained at bay.

The Consumer Price Index's "core" rate, which excludes food and energy costs, rose only 0.1 percent, triggering a big rally in bonds that sent interest rates falling and gave stock traders a green light to buy.
In the bond market, the benchmark 30-year Treasury bond gained a full point, cutting its yield to 6.77 percent from 6.85 percent at Monday's close.
"We had lot of reports today but most traders were hanging their hats on the CPI," said Robert Froehlich, chief investment strategist at Van Kampen American Capital.
Technology stocks were clear favourites for the day.
"We had an across-the-board run on technology stocks," said Arnie Owen, director of equities at Kaufman Brothers.

"There is a personal computer upgrade cycle going on in the corporate world and everyone is looking for a very good number out of Intel," he said, referring to Intel Corp.'s plans to release its quarterly earnings after the close.

Intel, the world's largest semiconductor maker did not disappoint, saying its fourth quarter earnings more than doubled to $1.9 billion amid surging sales of its popular Pentium and Pentium Pro microprocessors.
The Nasdaq Composite index jumped 15.45 points to a record 1,346.36. The Standard & Poor's composite index of 500 stocks rose 9.35 to 768.86, also a record.
The dollar surged to 1.5973 marks, its highest level since July 1994, following the release of subdued U.S. consumer price and retail sales figures for December.
The dollar rose to 1.5941 marks in late trading from 1.5887 late Monday. Against the yen, the dollar made a late push to break its early 117.04 high, but closed just shy at 116.93 vs. 116.48 yen.
Coffee prices rose to eight-month highs as speculators bought heavily on worries that supplies were falling faster than expected.
At the Coffee Sugar and Cocoa Exchange, March coffee futures ended 3.75 cents per pound higher at 122.20 cents, its highest settlement since May 17.
Overseas, London's FTSE 100 finished 60.9 points higher at a record 4,168.2. In Tokyo, the key Nikkei average of 225 leading shares closed 25.66 points or 0.14 percent lower at 18,093.13.
